Patient has small bumps all over his body that are very itchy.

symptom_text: Administered the vaccine and 1-2 minutes later the patient's eyes rolled in the back of his head and he became very stiff and couldn't communicate. It lasted for about 45 seconds then the patient came back and was talking.
lab_data: Dr evaluated the patient and administered fluids orally, checked BP, pulse and both were normal.

symptom_text: Patient developed headache and neck pain for 4-5 days. Went to the ER, initially diagnosed with viral meningitis. Symptoms continued with also some confusion and lethargy.  Respiratory panel revealed patient Mycoplasma pneumoniae positive and MRI revealed picture consistent with (ADEM) Acute Disseminated Encephalo Myelitis. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 03/19/13 Discharge summary received. Service dates 01/26/13 to 02/22/13. Diagnosis: ADEM (acute disseminated encephalomyelitis) Patient at lowest function was disoriented, lethargic, generalized weakness, non-communicative and incontinent. Benign murmur, episodes of bradycardia. Oral intake low. Viral gastroententeritis. Blurry vision. Cognitive deficits, impulsiveness, labile mood, behavioral changes. Broke tooth. IVIG, High dose steroids with increased strength, improved communication, more active though still sleeping through large parts of day. OT/PT.  02/25/13 ER, Hospital records, consultations received. Service dates 01/26/13 to 02/03/13. Additional information abstracted: Patient presents with head and neck pain, lying in bed with head turned to left, appears uncomfortable. Cough, sore throat, vomiting. Throat erythematous. Photophobia. Neck rigidity, muscle tenderness and pain with movement. Positive Brudzinski sign. Tachycardic. Tenderness right thigh. Body aches. Dehydration. IV Antibiotics. Decreased active range of motion in extremities. Unsteady in standing. Decreased attention, impaired memory, decreased comprehension, word-finding difficulties. Low verbal usage, speech slurred, dysarthria. Difficult to awaken.   03/21/13 PCP medical records received. Service date 03/06/13. Diagnosis: ADEM. Patient presents for post-hospitalization psychological services. Disinhibited verbal behavior.
lab_data: Respiratory panel - Mycoplasma pneumoniae +; Lumbar Puncture - WBC 125, Glucose 52, Protein 74; MRI - ADEM; Blood cx, Urine Cx, and CSF culture negative; Lyme ab negative, Enterovirus negative, HIV negative; CSF EBV, mycoplasma, and NMO pending The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 03/19/13 Labs and Diagnostics: ECG - Abnormal. Chest X-ray - Abnormal. Mycoplasma pneumoniae (+). MRI Brain - Abnormal. Urinary Ketones present. ESR 48 mm/hr (H). CBC - PLT 503 K/UL (H) MPV 6.8 FL (L) WBC 14.4 K/UL (H) HGB 12.9 G/DL (L) NEUTS 75% (H) LYMPHS 12% (L) ABS NEUTS 11.2 K/UL (H) ABS MONOS 1.2 K/UL (H), Anisocytosis, Poikilocytosis. CK <20 U/L (L).
history: Migraines, ADHD, Asthma The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 03/19/13 PMH: Asthma, ADHD, migraines. Myopia, eyeglasses.

symptom_text: Subjective dizziness, weakness, numbness with normal vital signs and physical exam throughout.
lab_data: Vital signs and physical exam normal throughout.  Suspect either anxiety or a vasovagal reaction.  Note, patient had venipuncture for lab tests done at same time.  The lab draw could also have been the cause.  Also, patient was being seen in clinic for depression and behavior problems at the time.  This underlying mental health condition may have contributed to her subjective symptoms.

symptom_text: Within 15min of vaccine administration Mother noted cough, followed by facial rash. Review of notes remarkable for rash described as macular rather than urticarial rash on the face, which subsequently spread to chest and back. Diphenhydramine and Prelone given without resolution of sxs. Epinephrine administered with prompt resolution of dermatitis and cough. Temperature increased to 100F from initial of 98.7. Child observed for several hours with NO recurrence of sxs. Sa02 notably normal (99-100 on RA), with normal oral/throat/respiratory/pulmonary examination. No angioedema reported. No GI sxs reported.
history: ADHD, coarct of aorta and VSD repaired at 3mos

symptom_text: Started with pain and stiffness in my R neck and shoulder, quickly progressed to a full blown migraine. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 2/20/2013 hospital records received for DOS 10/29-11/1/2012. D/c Dx's: 1) intracranial HTN ( pseudotumor cerebri); 2) HTN; 3) migraines; 4) bipolar disorder; 5) obesity. Pt c/o gradual onset sharp stabbing bilateral headache that radiates down back of neck into rt shoulder & wraps around rib cage, lightheadedness starting 2 hr s/p vaccination. Headache different from typical migraines. Additional c/o chills, SOB when pain is severe, rhinorrhea, polyuria. Walking around room talking on phone while waiting. PE: tachycardia, otherwise unremarkable. Admitted. Concern for idiopathic intracranial HTN. Pt d/c'd home w/ referral, Rxs, care & f/u instructions.   2/21/2013 ER records received for DOS 11/2/2012. Impression: headache, migraine variant vs pseudotumor cerebri. Pt c/o continuing headache, stiff neck, photophobia, nausea, possible IV site infection. PE unremarkable. D/c'd home in good condition w/ Rx, care instructions, & referral to neuro-ophthalmology clinic.  2/21/2013 ophthamologist records received for DOS 11/2/2012. Assessment: 1) migraine variant w/ status migrainosis; 2) subjective visual disturbance, unspecified. Pt referred from ER. PE: OS conjunctival injection, otherwise unremarkable.   2/21/2013 ER records received for DOS 1/24/2013. Impression: refractory migraine. Pt seen in f/u to evaluations above. PE unremarkable. Pseudotumor cerebri ruled out. Pt referred to pain clinic for migraine management.

symptom_text: Initial report received from a healthcare professional on 14 June 2012. A 16-year-old male patient, who had no known allergies or concomitant medication and whose medical history included ADHA, received a dose MENACTRA on 7 June 2012. On 7 June 2012, same day of vaccination, the patient developed urticaria with itchy red swollen hands and soles of the feet, swelling and reddening of palms of hands and soles of feet on an off. It is tender to touch and swelling and redness is progressing up the arms. The patient received ALLEGRA during the day and BENADRYL at night as corrective treatment. The patient was not recovered from the events. List of documents held by sender: none. Follow up information received on 14 September 2012: The patient did not receive any other vaccine within 4 weeks of the MENACTRA. The patient was receiving STRATTERA and RAPIDUS since as unknown date. The patient visited an allergist and was diagnosed was found to have urticaria and serum sickness type reaction (Arthus type reaction) to MENACTRA. He was treated with oral steroids after which the patient was fine.
history: The patient had no known allergies. Is a known case of ADHD. Concomitant medications were not reported. Follow up information received on 14 September 2012: The patient did not receive any other vaccine within 4 weeks of the MENACTRA. The patient was receiving STRATTERA and RAPIDUS since as unknown date.

symptom_text: Mom called day after vaccination, stated pt. had HPV and flu shot yesterday.  Went to schoool today, school nurse called mom to get him, had rash all over.  When she saw him, he had hives all over his body, looked beet red.  No lip swelling, or shortness of breath.  She gave him 25mg. of Benadryl. Nurse advised to give another 25mg, pt improved, but had flare ups of hives all over body for next two to three days requiring hydroxyzine, before resolving. Did not require any other therapy or physician visits. Parents and physician agreed he will not get the HPV again.

symptom_text: Initially I became very tired, but that was followed by day after day of lassitude, exploding headaches, daily heart palpitations, forgetfulness, difficulty spelling simple words, difficulty completing simple tasks like using my Ipad. Slurred speech, dizziness. Numbness in my hands and feet, shortness of breath. Noticable difficulty writing and swallowing. It all came to a climax 2/6/13 when I went to the doctor and I could not finish writing to fill out the paperwork, I was having trouble swallowing, trouble breathing and my legs became so weak, I could not walk. I had to have help just transferring. I was hospitalized from 2/6/13-2/8/13 supportive treatment with IV fluids and some therapy. I also had subsequent tests to rule out myasthenia gravis, MS, and ALS. These were ruled out and likewise TIA and CVA were both ruled out as well. I was just medically released to return to work 3/25/13 because I still had weakness, poor activity tolerance and intermittant dysarthria.
history: Mast Cell Activation Disorder, ADHD Allergies: Sulfa, IV Contrast Dye, Alcohol as a preservative, ASA

symptom_text: I began itching in random places all over my body at approximately 3:00pm, My skin was splotchy but no raised rash, by 3:30PM my bottom lip went completely numb and I noticed I felt like I had phlegm in my throat and was having trouble clearing. By 5:00PM the itching had became worse and my face began to itch and tingle, by 5:30pm the whole left side of my face was numb as well as my top lip. By 5:45PM my tongue was tingling and itching and when I looked at it, it was doubled in size and the back of my throat began to itch and I felt I was having difficulty breathing. I realized the itching was not normal like I had thought, when I noticed my face, tongue, and throat. I took 2 Benadryl immediately. I continued taking Benadryl every time I felt the reaction coming back as the pharmacist had instructed. I did this around the clock Friday evening and Saturday until around 9:00PM. When I realized the reaction time was getting closer together and the dose of Benadryl I had taken was no longer seeming to stop the reaction. The pharmacist had recommended going to the hospital if the last statement began happening and they would have to give me something to stop it. I went to the ER, arriving around 9:45PM and was given 60mgs of Prednisone orally shortly after. I was sent home with a prednisone prescription for 10mg tablet taper 5, 4, 3, 2, 1 to start on Sunday April 7th, 2013. The diagnoses was allergic reaction. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 4/10/2013 ER records received for DOS 4/6/2013. Dx: allergic reaction. Pt c/o 1 day hx SOB, itching, tongue swelling, throat tightness, difficulty swallowing. Took antihistamines prior to arrival, symptoms resolved on arrival. Given Rx for steroids, care & f/u instructions, referral to allergist.
other_meds: SMZ/TMP DS 800-160 TAB by mouth twice daily, but I had been on them 6 days and only took one at 10:00AM on the 7th day April 5, 2013, the date the vaccine was administered.
cur_ill: I was taking SMZ/TMP 800-160 TAB (Sulfamethoxazole and Trimethoprim) for a ingrown hair that had gotten infected on my groin/inner thigh. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. ABX for skin infection.
history: ADHD and Anxiety The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. PMH: ADD, anxiety.  Smoker.

symptom_text: Per MD note: "18-yr-old with Type 1 VWD received Hepatitis B reimmunization dose #3 of second series. Upon leaving clinic and reaching elevator stated he had deltoid and finger numbness. On questioning stated he had experienced immediate paresthesiae with sensation of a "furry caterpillar crawling from deltoid down arm". Numbness of dorsal surface of four fingers excluding thumb, also reported increased warmth in right hand compared to left. Objectively there was no significant bleeding at injection site. There was hyperemeia of the affected distal upper limb. Motor examination was completely normal." Given Benadryl 25mg po, observed in clinic. Injection site was 9 cm from acromion and in appropriate location with 1 inch needle. Upper arm circumferences was equal at 33cm. Eventual discharge from clinic around 5.50 pm."
lab_data: No labs, no testing as of 5/3/13.  Still has symptoms as described above.
other_meds: Humate-P prn bleeding episode, Stimate prn bleeding episode, Amicar prn bleeding episode (none were taken concomitantly with hepatitis B vaccine); Adderall XR 30mg 1 capsule by mouth daily.
history: Medical history: VWD Type 1, Epistaxis, Irritable Bowel Syndrome, Partial right ear hearing loss, ADHD; Allergies: Amoxicillin

symptom_text: Not even 10 minutes after the vaccine injection I felt cloudy headed but I thought it was my anxiety, I am not sure of the exact time it was maybe around 3:45. By approximately 4:00, I felt my ear go numb, and the right side of my face was tingling and my right eyelid went numb, I could feel the numbness spreading down my face on the right side. I immediately took a Benadryl, knowing the feeling from a previous vaccine reaction. I left the health department around 4:40 although I did not feel right but knowing that I had taken a Benadryl, I would hopefully be okay to make it home. By 7:15pm I felt I was having minor trouble breathing. So I took another Benadryl, and it did not seem to help by 7:40 approximately I took another Benadryl because I felt like I was suffocating and having to gasp for air and I was getting really light headed and felt like I was going to faint. My mother took me to hospital. I arrived there at approximately 8:00pm. Approximately 15-20 minutes after arriving I felt the Benadryl start working and breathing was not such a hard task. The doctor gave me a steroid pill 10mgs. (Not sure what kind, because it is not listed on my discharge paper) I was also given a 20mg Pepcid AC, I was told to take Pepcid AC if needed and to get help if the problem re-occurred and I was discharge with the diagnosis of vaccine reaction. Today 5/03/2013 I approximately 7:30 I felt I was starting to have breathing difficulty again and I took a Pepcid AC, and seem to be okay for now. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 5/6/2013 ER records received for DOS 5/2/2013. Assessment: SOB. Pt c/o paresthesias rt side of face 1 hr s/p vaccination. Self-medicated w/ antihistamine. Developed sensation of tightness in throat, difficulty breathing. Self medicated w/ additional antihistamine & albuterol inhaler. Symptoms resolved briefly. Presented to ER w/ diminishing SOB, anxiety. PE: anxious, otherwise unremarkable.
other_meds: I had taken my ADHD medication that morning which is generic Adderal IR 30mg.  **NOTE: I had an anaphylactic reation to the Varicella (Varivax) vaccine approximately 1 month ago. However, I have received 2 PPD test one at a clinic on 4/17
history: I am diagnosed with ADHD and anxiety, I had a prior reaction to the varicella vaccine. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. PMH: ADD, anxiety. Allergy: varicella vaccine. Smoker.

symptom_text: Mom says swelling, rash itchy. Itchy rash (papular) noted on both deltoids. No swelling noted today. (Local reaction).

Patient became white, began screaming-which lasted for hours, she began running a fever of 103.  I called the pediatrician and reported this event, and was "blown off" concerning it.  I was treated as an "over reacting" parent.  Patient began with ear infections and respiratory infections within days of this vaccine, the DTaP.  This child was PERFECTLY healthy until this vaccine was given.  Her illnesses with ear infections and respiratory infections has continued her whole life-the last 12+ years!  She has had ear tubes, adenoids and tonsils removed, she has episodes of severe blisters in her mouth, on her face hands and feet.  She has not made antibiodies to some vaccines that have been forced upon us. She was diagnosed with an IgA deficiency around age 3.  This child's illnesses have wreaked havoc on her life, and that of our family, and on our financial health, as well. I have NO doubt, after completing extensive research that the DTaP is the cause of my child's health issues. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 5/30/13 PCP medical records received. Service dates 9/5/00 to 3/15/13. Several visits. Drainage from PE tube on (R), antibiotics. Fever, raspy voice, asthma attack, URI.  6/27/13 Consultant, infectious diseases, medical records received. Service dates 1/26/09 to 9/6/11. Diagnoses: Typical Recurrent Orolabial HSV-1 infection. ADHD. Dysphagia/Globus. Patient presented lymphadenitis. MRSA. Later possible celiac disease. Constipation, diarrhea, heartburn, blood in stool, stomach pain, gassy, nausea, sore throat, enamel hyperplasia, skin rashes, easy bruising, poor growth, joint problems, immune problems, muscle weakness, allergies, frequent/unusual infections, swollen lymph nodes, chest pain, headaches, wheezing, asthma, shortness of breath, pneumonia. Stressed at school. Eyebrow injury, head trauma, from a kick from a horse. Surgical repair of foot and ankle after stepping through fish aquarium. Exposure to animals and sewage. Possible hookworms, mother has seen worms in stools. Chronic cough and chest wall symptoms associated with upper respiratory symptoms suggestive of allergic symptoms. Mild eosinophilia. Recurrent oral labial herpes simplex virus infections, previous diagnosis of hand-foot-mouth disease. Small cervical lymph node noted. Parent concern that child has "intestinal worm infestations" -  no conclusive diagnosis made but tx with antihelminthic drugs administered. Recurrent fever and other illnesses in the context of school. Puts hands and feet in mouth, recent weight gain of 20 pounds. Evaluation has yet to determine any major underlying medical concern.
lab_data: MANY!!! The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 6/27/13 Labs and Diagnostics: Viral Culture (+) for HSV-1 infection. Audiological Testing - Abnormal
cur_ill: None.  This child was PERFECTLY healthy, other than being premature.

During the week following the vaccines, patient was lethargic and irritable.  Within the week, he also began twitching during diaper changes.  The twitching started in his legs and gradually moved to his entire body.  We took him back to his family doctor who told us that he was fine & this reaction was normal. We ended up taking him to the emergency room two weeks later because we thought he was having seizures.  He was diagnosed with cerebral palsy.  Prior to his vaccinations, patient was a fully functioning, normally developing infant. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 6/18/2013 ER records received for DOS 7/9/2009. Dx's: 1) new onset of seizure; 2) possible schizencephaly.  Pt w/ 1 wk hx abnormal behavior: kicking LE, then stiffening & leaning head to side, glassy-eyed. Frequency of events increasing. PE: increased temperature (99.6 F), otherwise unremarkable. Pt transferred in stable condition for higher level care.   6/24/2013 hospital records received for DOS 7/9-10/2009. D/c Dx's: 1) seizure disorder; 2) rt-sided cerebral hemiatrophy & polymicrogyria.  Pt transferred w/ hx above. After admission pt had 2 20 sec episodes of stiffening, sprawling, shaking UE/LE, staring. Episodes followed by normal behavior. Pt d/c'd home in good condition w/ Rx, care & f/u instructions.   6/25 & 7/2/2013 PCP records received for DOS 6/28/2011-6/7/2013. Dx's: 1) CP; 2) seizure disorder. Pt followed for routine care. 7/8 c/o leg twitching during diaper changes. Thought to have had rt cerebral stroke in utero. Developmental delay, lt hemiplegia, dysphagia, esophageal reflux, visual disturbance, lt esotropia, OM, bronchitis, IBS, croup. Recurrent abscesses d/t MRSA. Tx;t: PT, ST, OT, Rx. Speech & eating abilities initially improved, then regressed some.  6/25/2013 neuro consultant records received for DOS 9/20/2011-4/19/2013. Assessment: 1) delayed milestones; 2) EEG revealed nonspecific abnormal findings; 3) abnormal weight gain; 4) hx of ketogenic dieting; 5) partial complex seizure; 6) hemiplegic CP; 7) ADHD, combined type. Pt followed w/ hx as above. Seizures difficult to control, Rx's altered as needed. C/o hyperactivity, acts w/o thinking, easily distracted, attention problems.  6/25/2013 allergy consultant records received for DOS 1/25/2013. Dx's: 1) lactose intolerance; 2) adverse food reaction to wheat. PCP referred pt w/ possible allergy to milk, wheat, & eggs. Pt c/o vomiting/diarrhea w/ large amounts of grains. Symptoms w/ milk c/w lactose intolerance. No problems w/ eggs. Given Rx for antihistamine & EpiPen, diet, care & f/u instructions.

symptom_text: < 24 hours after injection developed significant arm swelling, fever 103 degrees and pain. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 7/9/13 Hospital records and discharge summary received. Service dates 6/14/13 to 6/16/13. Diagnosis: Probable reaction to Pneumovax. Child presented after waking up at midnight with complaints of severe pain in right arm. Ibuprofen with some improvement. Later that morning pain became worse and swelling developed with wamth, erythema and tenderness concerning for cellulitis. Leukocytosis. Clindamycin and ceftriaxone. Toradol with good pain control. Better ROM of (R) arm. No tenderness to touch or palpation though upper and lower portion of arm remains swollen. DC to home, to finish 1 wk course of Augmentin.

symptom_text: Admitted 6/13 with headache, weakness and progressive mental status changes. CSF with 120 WBC, culture negative, MRI consistent with acute disseminated encephalomyelitis. Treated with IVIG and steroids. Became comatose, required intubation. Now recovering. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 7/23/13 ED, Hospital records and discharge summary received. Service dates 6/13/13 to 7/03/13. Diagnosis: Encephalomeningitis. Active problems - Aseptic meningitis, feeding difficulties, decreased level of conciousness, generalized weakness. Patient transferred from another facility with fever, headache, photophobia, lower extremity weakness, urinary retention/Foley catheter, nausea, vomiting. Mildly obese. Moaning while sleeping, abdominal pain. Pain upon neck flexion. Lower extremity paresthesias. PICU. Intubation due to worsening neuromuscular weakness, central line placement. IVIG administration. Difficulty swallowing, expressive aphasia. NG tube placement. Nystagmus, optic nerve swelling/papilledema. Cortical visual impairment. Inpatient rehabilitation.

symptom_text: Woke up with very bad headache and was screaming and crying for 5 min, mom gave him Tylenol and his headache started improving and he was back to normal in about an hour. He continued to do fine until later that evening when at 6:30 pm while getting out of the shower he started having severe headache again suddenly and started screaming again, mom tried giving him Tylenol which helped a little but he continued to have the headache and vomited 6 times so he was brought to the ER where BP was 146/82 on arrival and went up to 196/124. CT scan head was negative and lumbar puncture showed normal CSF except for elevated glucose. Diagnosed with hypertensive urgency, work-up was suggestive of catecholamine mediated hypertension. Imaging studies, that included MRI of abdomen/pelvis and head as wall as an MIBG scan were negative. Repeat urine and plasma studies for catecholamines and metanephrines were negative. Needed 2 anti-hypertensive medications with good effect and discharged home after 20 days in the hospital. Guanfacine, started 1 month prior to this episode was continued. Over the next 2 months, we were able to stop his antihypertensive medications. In the past 4 months, without anti-hypertensive medications, he has not had recurrence of headaches or hypertension.
lab_data: Hypertension work-up was suggestive of catecholamine mediated hypertension.

symptom_text: Immediately upon injection I had a painful burning sensation that went completely down to my fingertips. The shot administer told me to rub my arm throughout the day but the pain intensified on through the day and night to a point where I had limited mobility.  I then had to seek help from my family doctor. I was sent to an orthopedic doctor who then sent me to a neurologist who is sending me back to the orthopedic doctor.  I am still under doctor's care at this time. The following information was obtained through follow-up and/or provided by the government. 8/20/13 Orthopedic Consultant records received. Service dates 12/4/12 to 12/14/12. Diagnosis: Branchial plexopathy of left shoulder without cervical level involvement. Patient presents with shoulder pain and paresthesia since flu shot. Capsular and shoulder irritability. Trivial relief from shoulder injections - refer to neurologist.  9/5/13 Neurology Consultant records received. Service dates 5/20/13 to 6/15/13. Diagnosis: Acute Brachial Plexopathy, Arthrosis, subacromial subdeltoid bursitis. Patient presents for neurological evaluation, immediate pain in (L) deltoid, pain radiating to 2nd, 3rd, 4th fingers. Minimal degenerative changes C6-C7 Levels. Difficulty sleeping at night, intermittent blurred vision, urinary urgency and frequency, joint pain, anxiety. Tinel Sign (+) on right. Mild atrophy (L) trapezious and medial deltoid. Reflexes 1+ Ankles and knees.   9/3/13 Consultant medical records received. Service dates 11/6/12 Diagnosis: Hypertension uncontrolled, (L) shoulder and (R) leg discomfort. Patient presents with 40 lb weight loss, left shoulder pain, pain in right lower leg at night.

This spontaneous report as received from a licensed vocational nurse refers to a 14 year old male patient with acne and attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD and a history of insomnia and no drug reactions or allergies who on 20-JUL-2011, was vaccinated intramuscularly with the first 0.5 ml dose of GARDASIL (lot number 669285/0691AA, Exp. Date: 17-AUG-2013) and on 08-AUG-2013, was vaccinated with the second dose of GARDASIL (lot number J002641, Exp. Date: 10-DEC-2015). Concomitant therapies included Sulfacetamide sodium, Clonidine, VENTOLIN HFA, RETIN-A MICRO GEL, and Benzoyl peroxide (+) Clindamycin phosphate. The nurse reported that on 15-AUG-2013, the patient's father called to the office regarding a lump in his son throat. The patient was seen in the office on 16-AUG-2013 and the physician diagnosed the patient with lymph node enlargement. Antibiotics, warm compress and Ibuprofen were given as a treatment for the experience. At the time of the report, the patient had not recovered. The relatedness for lymph node enlargement and GARDASIL was unknown. Additional information has been requested.

Given some candy and water and asked to lay down. An ice pack was applied to the head due to hitting it when seizing. About 20 min. later the patient walked out of the clinic on her own after being evaluated by a MD.

symptom_text: Local reaction to L upper arm (site of VAR administration). Arm swollen, warm to touch and red with 8x8 cm induration. Ice pack and Ibuprofen given. Youth denies pain and itching.
Red rash from armpit to wrist, swelling, extreme tenderness.
Vasovagal response HR decreased 54 BPM. Pt placed in a supine position until able to determine if stable. Monitored w/O2 Sat. Continuously monitoring in room VS taken.

After administration of HPV in left arm patient just looked straight ahead. I asked patient if she felt light headed and she said yes. I had her lay down. She did not have any loss of consciousness. Upon laying down she stared straight ahead. Her Uncle was asked to come back to the room and Dr. was brought into the room to exam patient. I asked her to tell me her name, where she was, why she was here. She slowly answered all questions appropriately. At that time she had left arm twitching that lasted about 6-7 minutes. All vitals with in normal limits. 911 was called due to starring, delayed speech and left arm twitching that did not stop. Once ambulance arrived patient's arm twitching had stopped, she was sitting up and able to answer all questions appropriately with out and any delay. Escorted to hospital by ambulance. Called to see patient about 5 mins after HPV injection. When I entered room, patient was supine on the bed, staring with LUE shaking. She responded in a slurred voice to questions but answered correctly. No eye deviation, but appeared to be staring, ? left mouth drooling. She was able to squeeze right UE but left was weaker. Uncle in the room had never seen this prior. No recent illnesses per uncle. On phone conversation her aunt denies any previous seizure history or pseudoseizure. No new medications. Complex psych history and social situation. Reviewed last WCC. VSS as below (HR 76, O2 96%, BP as below) entire event were stable. LUE twitching continued > 6 minutes. Due to decreased LOC and continued shaking, EMS was called. On their arrival she was alert and shaking had stopped. She stated "what happened?" but then could relay events. No weakness and normal neuro exam otherwise she was tearful. Reviewed events with aunt, via phone and also EMS. DDX - pseudoseizure vs partial seizure vs stress event. Referred to ED for further care given change in LOC, via ambulance.
8/21/13 - Heache and arm twitching episodes, 40 min to 2 hours in legnth. Neg EEG. Diagnosed with pseudoseizures. See neuro notes. 10/1 - Present - Abd pain - see 2 x ER notes.

This spontaneous retrospective pregnancy report as received from a 22 year old female consumer with no Pertinent Medical History and no Drug Reactions/Allergies refers to her son. On an unknown date in October 2007 the son was received a dose of GARDASIL, injection, (lot #, expiration, dose and route unspecified), transplacentally. No concomitant medication was provided. Sometime in October 2007, since receiving GARDASIL, the mother stated that she had developed many "medical issues," including "liver disease, allergies, irritable bowel syndrome and a hiatal hernia." The mother stated that her son (who was conceived when the mother received GARDASIL) had developed autism and was legally blind. No demographics were provided for the son. The reporter stated that her son had also developed "a sleep disorder, a developmental coordination disorder, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD), an orthopedic disorder and a mixed disorder of conduct and emotions. The outcome of son's event was unknown. Upon internal review, the event of legally blind was considered as medically significant. This is one of several reports received from same source. Additional information has been requested.

symptom_text: 10/16/13 -Patient left our house suddenly and without permission. Later he said he did not remember leaving.  As his awareness returned and he saw he was on his way to school, he just walked to school and was taken in by staff. 10-21-13 - 6 PM - Patient once again left our house and later he again said, he didn't remember leaving. He was found by police over a mile from home going through people's mailboxes looking for 'his catalog'. He said he was heading to his daycare facility which was over 2 miles and a major highway away.  The week of 10-21-13 - patient had great difficulty processing, unable to remember known words while reading, respond appropriately to daily directions and was constantly argumentative in every setting. None of these behaviors were typical during the given time. All behaviors have stopped by 10-28-13. Dr. has referred patient to a pediatric neurologist to investigate potential seizure activity caused by either vaccine or medication and/or the onset of other neurological disorders, impairments.
Patient developed muscle spasms and stiffness diffusely within 15-30 minutes of flu shot injection. Taken to ER by mom.

While waiting in office following vaccines, he developed a cough, watery eyes and a red blotchy rash to his chest with some swelling of the left hand.  His exam was otherwise normal, with no difficulty swallowing and no wheezing.  O2 was 100%.  He was given 25 mg of Benadryl and calmed down, but kept with cough and tiredness.
